2020-08-30.text: Depends, could be anywhere between 10% to over 35% of your body. Stevens-Johnson Syndrome can go Super Saiyan and become TENS (Toxic Epidermal Necrolysis) so it’s difficult to say.

2020-08-29.text: 1/2500 is rare ish but not rare enough to put me at ease. It’s why they start off at such a low dose and gradually increase it, once you’ve adjusted to the full dose I imagine you’re in the clear but those early days are crucial it seems.

Strange, it’s been my experience that physicians routinely discuss adverse effects of medications, though I also always ask about them.  It’s called Stevens-Johnson Syndrome, a simple google image search was all it took to convince me I’d rather just be fuckin depressed.

Why are pharmaceuticals like this? Why is the option of relief almost always accompanied by the possibility of anal leakage, nausea, diarrhea, seizure, stroke or death? (though I'd take anal leakage over skin sloughing off any day).

The proverbial chicken or the egg, does the ADHD exacerbate the BD or the other way around. I wound up having a dysphoric response to the Adderall so we decided to axe that and stabilize my mood first. Only I'm not exactly keen on my options.

And since my particular form of Bipolar means I don't really experience mania, alternatives like Lithium would not be as effective. Having a comorbidity like ADHD and BD while not terribly uncommon, represents a particularly tricky predicament.
I asked for alternatives, and was informed that they too pose significant side effects, that are even more likely to occur, so much so that I'd need regular blood work to monitor toxicity levels.
It would be prescribed as a mood stabilizer, though I'm not sure how stable I'd be if I came out the other end like Major Toht in Raiders of the Lost Ark.

My psychiatrist would like to prescribe Lamictal (Lamotrigine) which apparently has a 1/2500 chance of causing your skin to slough off. While this side effect is deemed rare, I don't know if it's worth that 0.04% as I'm rather attached to my skin...pun intended.

And suddenly, you’re back.  Some notice. Some never realize you were gone. Fewer still, know the true peril in which you were placed, if only just for a moment, as it was in this moment that you were utterly exposed to something unspeakably dark & foreboding.

And in that moment you’re completely isolated, paralyzed by fear, anxiety and despair as the sinister shrieks & whispers snake their way into your mind while you await whatever fate they have in store.

Depression is like slipping into the unseen realm, becoming invisible to everyone around you. And yet you shine like a beacon in the darkness  drawing the attention of all manor of wraith & cursed creatures and all you can do is watch as they draw near.

My tits are currently being held in a tower, guarded by a fearsome dragon, known only in the realm of Viktoria’s Dyrne. One pound of gold shall be had by any man or woman who manages to bring me its head

2020-08-03.text: I’ve heard my share of “you’re too intense” & “you’re a handful”.  I keep people on their toes, that’s for sure 😂
Also, it’s hard enough going through puberty, being a teenager, navigating school all while shouldering the weight of ADHD.  Those were rough years 😅

Sounds like you’re doing your best to be a good parent and the fact that you’re aware of and accepting of the diagnosis is awesome.  It was difficult on my parents.  We fought a lot.  For a while they didn’t think ADHD was real, that I was just being rebellious and lazy.
Becoming aware of and accepting that, let alone working through it, is a challenge all on its own.  Gotta give yourself some awareness points for that 🤙🏻

There’s so much more information and available resources now than there was when I was growing up. Being aware of and active in your sons continued development is crucial. It’ll be challenging for all involved, but encouragement and patience goes a long way.

2020-08-02.text: If you figure out how to break the cycle let me know 😂
a rare item drop glowing with possibilities.  And I’m prepared to level and grind until I get it.

I’m about to enter week three of Adderall, so far, I’ve yet to notice any changes but it’s still early days and I’m prepared to embark on what will likely be trial and error, but for the first time in over twenty years I’m hopeful.  There’s a faint light at the end of the tunnel

And when I still struggled and therapy, while indeed helpful, wasn’t enough, I finally accepted the fact that I may need medication.  That I had to shatter my own misconceptions and stigmas surrounding medication, that it didn’t mean weakness, but a willingness to succeed.

That in spite of the fact I’d continue to face challenges and obstacles, I had resources.  I was just a square peg trying to fit in a round hole.  And now was the time to explore other options.  Maybe pursue the more creative endeavors I’d only ever daydreamed about.

I left feeling utterly defeated.  Angry with myself for being this way.  Resentful, ashamed and embarrassed.
Until I accepted the fact that I worked with a group of intolerant assholes incapable of thinking outside the box.

It took every fiber of my being not to lash out in a brilliant display of white hot rage, but I held it together and reacted with tact and professionalism.  I requested they be banned from the clinic (patients who threaten and attack staff often are) my request was declined.

I was sent home for the day to “think about it”.  I called HR to file a report, when I was met with apathy, I knew it was a losing battle.  I lasted another week before I quit on the spot after nearly being attacked by a disgruntled patient...

I gave pushback, through tears, I explained my ADHD meant I learn differently, not that I couldn’t learn.  That I wanted this job, that I could DO this job.  I was then told that I should just quit, that my “condition” meant it wasn’t a good fit.

So I took it to the supervisor, who then went on to defend and excuse their behavior and was asked to put myself in their shoes, how frustrating it must be to be asked so many questions, to require more attention that I was placing unnecessary strain on them.

It was eventually granted but not without ridicule.  I was made to feel like an inconvenience.  I was also asked to show proof of my diagnosis, so I did.  During the training, I was chastised, alienated and mocked by my peers.  I was met with retaliation when I addressed this.

as the mortification set in.  But this time, I spoke up.  I asked questions.  I asked more questions.  I felt as though I had a pretty good grasp on things.  I just needed a little more time.  So I requested accommodation in way of an expansion in my training.

When raising my hand meant revealing myself as dumb, hearing the sighs of my classmates and the impatient tone of my teacher as they called upon me for the dozenth time.  Feeling the sweat begin to form on my forehead and neck, feeling hot as my complexion turned bright red

Not the most engaging of topics, but I tried to sit still, listen, and follow along but found myself feeling like I did all those years in school, when the rest of the class was onto the next chapter and I was still stuck on the first one, and combating endless distractions.

I reached a breaking point when I had accepted a job at a well known clinic, and underwent off site training which meant sitting in a computer lab, while a bored instructor droned on about patient registration, billing and filing health insurance claims.

After some years of therapy, my comprehension of ADHD and how the neurodivergent brain works had expanded greatly, so much made sense.  But the struggles remained, unraveling years of internalized stigmas and unhealthy coping mechanisms would take time.

Like a wounded animal, I sought to avoid being noticed for my weaknesses and picked off from the rest of the herd.  I internalized my shame, guilt, anger and humiliation and did my best to camouflage myself into a society that favors the neurotypical brain.

What was ordinarily considered life’s typical dilemmas was to me an obstacle rigged with minefields and traps.  The anxiety was often so overwhelming that I’d avoid challenges and thus opportunities.  If no one saw me fail, my struggles would go undetected.
Maintaining, let alone initiating relationships both romantic and platonic was arduous and rife with difficulty.  I went through as many relationships as I did jobs.

My opposition to authority meant more challenges and long term consequences in adulthood than in adolescence.  Becoming excessively frustrated or emotional at work when I had difficulty comprehending a task or when co-workers or customers were judgmental or rude.
my inability to sleep, focus, retain or process information as effectively as my peers.  The restlessness, anxiety, mood swings, and outbursts.

and that’s when it became painfully evident that it was so much more than that.  That it has affected every aspect of my life, bahviorally, socially and cognitively.  That it was responsible for my mood dysregulation, limited functioning memory, sensory overload and depression

I was diagnosed with ADHD in the 4th grade.  Spent my entire life thinking it was just inattention/hyperactivity/impulsivity.  A learning deficit.  It wasn’t until I began therapy that my understanding of ADHD expanded beyond the scope of its generic stereotypes
